did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: This collection contains a screenplay for the film Where the Heart Is. The finished product contains scenes shot on Baylor University's campus.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Where the Heart Is was a film directed by Matt Williams in 2000. Screenwriters Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel adapted the screenplay from author Billie Lett’s best-selling novel (1995). This film project was the first time Matt Williams directed a feature length film. He had won prior acclaim as a creator and executive producer for the successful television series Roseanne and Home Improvement. Natalie Portman, an up-and-coming star at the time, played the lead role in the film alongside actresses Ashley Judd and Joan Cusack.

The screenplay was given to Baylor University by director Matt Williams as a gesture of appreciation. On 1999 August 16 the production crew filmed scenes at various locations across Baylor University's campus including Pat Neff Hall and Armstrong Browning Library. Due to its resemblance to prestigious East Coast campuses, Baylor University served as a fictional college campus in Maine. Many Baylor students volunteered as extras for the film.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a single, pre-production draft of a screenplay for the 2000 film adaptation of Where the Heart Is. The screenplay contains various revisions made by the crew from 1999 April to August. The item was autographed by director Matt Williams and actress Natalie Portman and is in excellent condition.

Based on the 1995 novel by Billie Letts, Where the Heart Is follows the fictitious story of a 17-year-old pregnant teenager named Novalee Nation who is portrayed in the film by Natalie Portman. While leaving Tennessee to move to California, Novalee is abandoned by her boyfriend at a Walmart in Sequoyah, Oklahoma. The plot of the film follows the residents of the town as they rally around Novalee.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to the current processing, this screenplay was housed in an acid-free folder with a basic description. The collection has since been re-housed and arranged into a single series, I. Literary Productions.
